taskbody.context: In this section of the lab exercise you will bundle, upload, and register the new customized image. Then you will launch an instance from the image, synchronize its time using NTP, run a euca2ools command, and check that the new /etc/fstab file is working correctly.

step.cmd: On the front-end host, bundle, upload, and register your new image. Bundle the new EMI with the existing EKI and ERI that appear in the output of the euca-describe-images command. Upload the bundle to a new bucket named kvm-centos. It will take a minute or two for the bundling of the image to complete.

info.codeblock: # cd /var/images # ls # euca-describe-images # euca-bundle-image -i kvm-centos-5.8.img --kernel eki-<nnnnnnnn> \ --ramdisk eri-<nnnnnnnn> # euca-upload-bundle -b kvm-centos -m /tmp/kvm-centos-5.8.img.manifest.xml # euca-register kvm-centos/kvm-centos-5.8.img.manifest.xml

step.cmd: View your new EMI. It should be the one in the kvm-centos bucket.
Launch a new instance using the EMI of your newly customized CentOS image. It will be the EMI in the kvm-centos bucket.
Monitor the instance until it reaches a running state. It might take 1-2 minutes longer to boot as it is de-installing and reinstalling software as it boots.
Use SSH to log in to the new instance.
On the instance, update the instance’s time with NTP.
Source the .bashrc file and verify that the eucarc file environment variables were set.
Test the operation of euca2ools by viewing the public IP address pool in your cloud.
Log out of the instance but leave it running.
On the front-end host, launch a second instance using the original EMI. It will be the EMI in the centos bucket. Monitor it until it reaches a running state.
Use SSH to log in to the instance you just launched using the original EMI image in the centos bucket.
In the instance, view the mounted file systems and the available swap space using the df –h and swapon –s commands.

info.p: Which file systems are mounted? Which swap area is available? Write them down.

step.cmd: Use SSH to log back in to the new instance launched from the EMI in the kvm-centos bucket.
In the instance, view the mounted file systems and the available swap space using the df –h and swapon –s commands.

info.p: Which file systems are mounted? Which swap area is available? Write them down. How do they compare to the instance launched from the original EMI. What is missing? This is why you modified the image’s /etc/fstab file earlier in this lab.

step.cmd: On the front-end host, terminate both instances.
